title: Example on how to change and run a model
text: Now use process error tuned file fix vales “ssb” files
code: d1 <- read_dat("runs/dat/proctune1.dat") d2 <- read_dat("runs/dat/pm_ssb0.dat") d3            <- d2 d3$n_avo      <- d1$n_avo d3$ob_avo     <- d1$ob_avo d3$ob_avo_std <- d1$ob_avo_std d3$wt_avo     <- d1$wt_avo d3$yrs_avo    <- d1$yrs_avo  write_dat(output_file="runs/dat/pm_ssb0new.dat", indata=d3)  # Create directory and copy key files dir.create("runs/ssb0") file.copy("runs/ssb0_origProcTune/control.dat","runs/ssb0/",overwrite = TRUE) file.copy("runs/avon2/compweights.ctl","runs/ssb0/",overwrite = TRUE) file.remove("runs/ssb0/pm") file.symlink("../../src/pm","runs/ssb0/pm") # Read pm.dat, then write (e.g.,)   pm.dat<-read_table("runs/ProcTune/pm.dat",col_names=FALSE) # Add some description of the rows...   row.names(pm.dat) <- c("Desc","main","sel","ctl","altFmsy","cov","wtage","cpue","temp","q")   pm.dat   pm.dat[1,] <- "Updated_SSB0_to_proctune1"   pm.dat[2,] <- "../dat/pm_ssb0new.dat"   writeLines(as.character(pm.dat$X1),"runs/ssb0/pm.dat")

what: Now run them all in parallel
title: Example on how to change and run a model
code: mod_dir   <- c("ProcTune","ssb0","ssb1","ssb2")   mod_names <- c("Proc_error_Tune","ssb0","ssb1","ssb2")   # output=TRUE default, also check on spm   res <- run_model()   #res <- get_results()   tab_fit(res, mod_scen = c(1:2)) |> gt::gt()   tab_fit(res, mod_scen = c(1:4)) |> gt::gt()   tab_ref(res, mod_scen = c(1:4)) |> gt::gt() |> gt::fmt_markdown()      # See if different from base   tail(sc2)   ctl <-read_dat("runs/ProcTune/control.dat")   ctlb <-read_dat("runs/base22/control.dat")   diff <- purrr::map_lgl(names(ctl), ~ !identical(ctl[[.]], ctlb[[.]]))   sum(diff)   names(ctl[diff])   cbind(ctl[diff][2],ctlb[diff][2])   names(ctl)   ctl[56]   write_dat("runs/base22/control.dat",ctl)  # Set an initial working directory   mod_names <- c("AVON Full","Proc_tune")   mod_dir <- c("avon2", "ProcTune")   # Note, 0.2 CV for selectivity variability nails it (from base22)   # Read, adjust, write...   sc <-read_table("runs/dat/scmed22P.dat",col_names = FALSE); names(sc) <- c("Year","fsh","bts","ats")   tail(sc )   # Iterated on selectivity   sc2 <-  sc |> mutate(ats = ifelse(ats>0,.138,0))   write.table(sc2,file="runs/dat/scmed22P.dat",col.names = FALSE,row.names = FALSE)   #modtune <- run_model(Output=TRUE)   modtune<-get_results()   tab_fit(modtune, mod_scen = c(1,2)) |> gt::gt()   tab_ref(modtune, mod_scen = c(1,2)) |> gt::gt()   tab_ref(modlst, mod_scen = c(4,5)) |> gt::gt()   (modlst[[4]]$nextyrssbs)   (modlst[[4]]$nextyrssb.sd)   (modtune[[1]]$nextyrssbs)   names(modtune)

title: SAFE report front matter
text: Walleye pollock (Gadus chalcogrammus; hereafter referred pollock) broadly distributed throughout North Pacific largest concentrations found Eastern Bering Sea. Also known Alaska pollock, species continues play important roles ecologically economically.

title: SAFE report front matter
text: EBS pollock spawn generally period March-May relatively localized regions specific periods (Bailey 2000). Generally spawning begins nearshore north Unimak Island March April later near Pribilof Islands (Jung et al. 2006, Bacheler et al. 2010). Females batch spawners 10 batches eggs per female per year (peak spawning period). Eggs larvae EBS pollock planktonic period 90 days appear sensitive environmental conditions. conditions likely affect dispersal favorable areas (subsequent separation predators) also affect general food requirements -wintering survival (Gann et al. 2015, Heintz et al., 2013, Hunt et al. 2011, Ciannelli et al. 2004). Duffy-Anderson et al. (2015) provide review early life history EBS pollock. Throughout range juvenile pollock feed variety planktonic crustaceans, including calanoid copepods euphausiids. EBS shelf region, one-year-old pollock found throughout water column, also commonly occur NMFS bottom trawl survey. Ages 2 3 year old pollock rarely caught summer bottom trawl survey gear common midwater zone detected mid-water acoustic trawl surveys. Younger pollock generally found northern parts survey area appear move southeast age (Buckley et al. 2009). Euphausiids, principally Thysanoessa inermis T. raschii, among important prey items pollock Bering Sea (Livingston, 1991; Lang et al., 2000; Brodeur et al., 2002; Cianelli et al., 2004; Lang et al., 2005). Pollock diets become piscivorous age, cannibalism commonly observed region. title: Executive summary
text: recent warm stanza eastern Bering Sea (EBS) persisted approximately 2014 2021. Since 2021, EBS experienced cooler oceanographic conditions recent year’s metrics sea surface bottom temperatures, sea ice, cold pool extent near respective time series averages. Regional sea surface bottom temperature trends largely near long-term average 2023. Exceptions include () slightly warmer average sea surface temperature (SST) outer domain (southern northern shelf) southern middle domain approximately December 2022 April 2023 (ii) slightly cooler average bottom temperature outer domain southern shelf August 2022 August 2023. Due exceptions, outer domain may strongly vertically stratified system late winter/early spring 2022-2023. standard bottom trawl survey summer 2023, bottom temperatures slightly cooler time series average coldest bottom temperatures southern inner domain since 2013. Marine heatwaves based SSTs brief infrequent EBS since January 2021 (Hennon et al., 2023). Age-0 fish experiencing warm temperatures late summer followed relatively cooler temperatures spring age-1 thought average survival. Based Temperature Change index, 2022 year class predicted average recruitment age-4 2026 (Yasumiishi, 2023). Sea ice metrics, early season (Oct. - Dec.) ice extent, annual ice extent, sea ice thickness near respective time series averages. 2023 cold pool extent also near historical average. Broad-scale climate indices, like North Pacific Index, reflected transition La Niña conditions developing El Niño conditions tropic Pacific; National Multi-Model Ensemble predicts SST anomalies +0.5-1°C SEBS shelf May 2024 (Hennon et al., 2023). center gravity estimate pollock moved steadily north since approximately 2000, shifted fairly south 2022, north 2023 (though northward position). stock center gravity also moved east 2010 2017, shifted west approximately time series average 2023. area occupied stock steadily expanded since 2010, exception 2018, since decreased since 2019 remains time series average 2023 (@fig-cog).

title: Executive summary
text: Chlorophyll-biomass among lowest every sub-region southern northern shelf slope 2023 (Nielsen et al., 2023). Additionally, 2023, coccolithophore index inner middle shelf among highest ever observed timeseries. striking milky aquamarine color water coccolithophore bloom can reduce foraging success visual predators, fish surface-feeding seabirds (Nielsen Eisner, 2023). Modeled bottom pH Ωarag (important pteropod shell formation) improved year compared lowest near-lowest values model hindcast 2022, though remain near threshold levels biological significance (Pilcher et al., 2023). Small copepods form prey base larval early juvenile pollock spring. Late juvenile pollock feed variety planktonic crustaceans, including large calanoid copepods euphausiids. Rapid Zooplankton Assessment southeastern Bering Sea spring noted moderate abundance small copepods, low abundance low lipid content large copepods euphausiids. fall, moderate abundance small copepods continued, abundance large copepods euphausiids remained low, abundances increased south north. northern Bering Sea fall, small copepods ubiquitous increased abundance south north, hot spots large copepods euphausiids observed around St. Lawrence Island (Kimmel et al. 2023). significant relationship exists abundance large, lipid-rich copepods recruitment survival juvenile pollock age-3 (Eisner et al., 2020). Low availability large copepod prey 2020 2022 may result reduced overwinter survival recruitment age-3 (2023 2025) (Yasumiishi et al., 2023b). Age-0 fish condition (samples collected southern northern Bering Sea surface trawl surveys), measured length-weight residuals, % lipid content, energy density residuals, respective time series averages 2023. Length-weight energy density residuals show decreasing trends since 2021 mean % lipid average (time series 2002-2023) since beginning recent warm stanza 2014 (Page et al., 2023). Juvenile (100-250 mm) fish condition southern Bering Sea decreased since 2021 adult fish condition decreased since 2019 2023 second lowest time series (1997-2023). Juvenile fish condition northern Bering Sea decreased since 2021 adult fish condition increased since 2021 2023 highest time series (2010, 2017, 2019, 2021-2023) (Prohaska Rohan, 2023).

title: Executive summary
text: Jellyfish feed primarily zooplankton small fish, therefore may compete prey resources juvenile adult life stages pollock. Jellyfish abundance southeastern Bering Sea shelf average time series (1982-2023; Buser, 2023), whereas abundance increased northern Bering Sea shelf (Buser, 2023; Yasumiishi et al., 2022c). Togiak herring biomass increasing recent years result strong 2016 2017 year classes also contributed high Prohibited Species Catch EBS pollock fishery (Joy et al., 2023). Yukon Kuskokwim River salmon runs experienced precipitous declines recent years (Whitworth et al., 2023), leading potential reduced competition prey resources stocks overlap, though slight increases observed juvenile Chinook chum salmon indices 2023 (Murphy et al., 2023). 2023, returns Bristol Bay sockeye salmon remained exceptionally high relative long-term average, lower recent record high numbers observed 2021 2022 (Cunningham Vega, 2023). Juvenile sockeye salmon feed zooplankton (competitors age-0 pollock) age-0 pollock (competitors adult pollock) warm years; adults feed zooplankton krill. Juvenile salmon condition 2022, measured energy density anomalies, negative species (except neutral Chinook salmon) southeastern Bering Sea positive species (except neutral sockeye salmon) northern Bering Sea (Fergusson et al., 2023). biomass pelagic foragers measured standard EBS bottom trawl survey decreased 34% 2022 2023 long-term mean (1982-2023) now third lowest value. guild largely driven walleye pollock decreased 25% 2022. Pacific herring decreased 75% time series high 2022, remain long-term mean (Siddon, 2023). impacts recent large year classes sablefish EBS ecosystem (prey, predators, competitors) remain largely unknown time, may compete pollock prey resources juveniles.

title: Executive summary
text: Pollock cannibalistic rates cannibalism might expected increase biomass older, larger fish increases (.e., aging large 2018 year class). 2023, average cold pool extent shelf, predation pressure cannibalism may mitigated thermal barrier adult pollock tend avoid cold bottom waters. However, biomass pelagic foragers, including adult pollock, dropped third lowest value time series 2023 (Siddon, 2023). Fur seal consumption adult pollock generally increases years juvenile pollock less abundant (Kuhn et al., 2019). However, Northern fur seal pup production St. Paul Island 2022 continued declining trend since 1998 may partially attributed low pup growth rates. potential predators juvenile pollock include jellyfish chum salmon. Jellyfish abundance southeastern Bering Sea shelf average time series (1982-2023; Buser, 2023), whereas abundance increased northern Bering Sea shelf (Buser, 2023; Yasumiishi et al., 2022c). Chum salmon abundance declining Yukon Kuskokwim Rivers since 2017 (Whitworth et al., 2023), trend also reflected commercial harvest data (Whitehouse, 2023).

Given concerns listed , recommend reducing ABC value provided Tier 3 projections. table applied evaluating severity four types considerations used support scientific recommendation reduce ABC maximum permissible. Examples types concerns might relevant include following (identified work-group): Assessment considerations Data-inputs: biased ages, skipped surveys, lack fishery-independent trend data Model fits: poor fits fits fishery survey data, inability simultaneously fit multiple data inputs. Model performance: poor model convergence, multiple minima likelihood surface, parameters hitting bounds. Estimation uncertainty: poorly-estimated influential year classes. Retrospective bias biomass estimates. Population dynamics considerations—decreasing biomass trend, poor recent recruitment, inability stock rebuild, abrupt increase decrease stock abundance. Environmental/ecosystem considerations–trends environmental/ecosystem indicators, ecosystem model results, decreases ecosystem productivity, decreases prey abundance availability, increases increases predator abundance productivity. Fisheries considerations–fishery CPUE showing contrasting pattern stock biomass trend, unusual spatial pattern fishing, changes percent TAC taken, changes duration fishery openings.”

title: Executive summary
text: EBS pollock generally spawn March-May relatively localized regions specific periods (@bailey2000 ). Generally spawning begins nearshore north Unimak Island March April later near Pribilof Islands (@bacheler2010). Females batch spawners 10 batches eggs per female per year (peak spawning period). Eggs larvae EBS pollock planktonic period 90 days appear sensitive environmental conditions. conditions likely affect dispersal favorable areas (subsequent separation predators) also affect general food requirements -wintering survival (@gann2015, @heintz2013, @hunt2011, @ciannelli2004). @duffy2016 provide review early life history EBS pollock. Throughout range juvenile pollock feed variety planktonic crustaceans, including calanoid copepods euphausiids. EBS shelf region, one-year-old pollock found throughout water column, also commonly occur NMFS bottom trawl survey. Ages 2 3 year old pollock rarely caught summer bottom trawl survey gear common midwater zone detected mid-water acoustic trawl surveys. Younger pollock generally found northern parts survey area appear move southeast age (@buckley2009). Euphausiids, principally Thysanoessa inermis T. raschii, among important prey items pollock Bering Sea (@livingston1991; @lang2000; @brodeur2002; @ciannelli2004; @lang2005). Pollock diets become piscivorous age, cannibalism commonly observed region. However, @buckley2015 showed spatial patterns pollock foraging varies size predators. example, northern part shelf region 100 200 m isobaths (closest shelf break) tends piscivorous pollock found near-shore shallow areas.

title: Executive summary
text: recent warm stanza eastern Bering Sea (EBS) persisted approximately 2014 2021. Since 2021, EBS experienced cooler oceanographic conditions recent year’s metrics sea surface bottom temperatures, sea ice, cold pool extent near respective time series averages. Regional sea surface bottom temperature trends largely near long-term average 2023. Exceptions include () slightly warmer average sea surface temperature (SST) outer domain (southern northern shelf) southern middle domain approximately December 2022 April 2023 (ii) slightly cooler average bottom temperature outer domain southern shelf August 2022 August 2023. Due exceptions, outer domain may strongly vertically stratified system late winter/early spring 2022-2023. standard bottom trawl survey summer 2023, bottom temperatures slightly cooler time series average coldest bottom temperatures southern inner domain since 2013. Marine heatwaves based SSTs brief infrequent EBS since January 2021 (Hennon et al., 2023). Age-0 fish experiencing warm temperatures late summer followed relatively cooler temperatures spring age-1 thought average survival. Based Temperature Change index, 2022 year class predicted average recruitment age-4 2026 (Yasumiishi, 2023). Sea ice metrics, early season (Oct. - Dec.) ice extent, annual ice extent, sea ice thickness near respective time series averages. 2023 cold pool extent also near historical average. Broad-scale climate indices, like North Pacific Index, reflected transition La Niña conditions developing El Niño conditions tropic Pacific; National Multi-Model Ensemble predicts SST anomalies +0.5-1°C SEBS shelf May 2024 (Hennon et al., 2023). center gravity estimate pollock moved steadily north since approximately 2000, shifted fairly south 2022, north 2023 (though northward position). stock center gravity also moved east 2010 2017, shifted west approximately time series average 2023. area occupied stock steadily expanded since 2010, exception 2018, since decreased since 2019 remains time series average 2023 (@fig-cog).

title: Executive summary
text: Chlorophyll-biomass among lowest every sub-region southern northern shelf slope 2023 (Nielsen et al., 2023). Additionally, 2023, coccolithophore index inner middle shelf among highest ever observed timeseries. striking milky aquamarine color water coccolithophore bloom can reduce foraging success visual predators, fish surface-feeding seabirds (Nielsen Eisner, 2023). Modeled bottom pH Ωarag (important pteropod shell formation) improved year compared lowest near-lowest values model hindcast 2022, though remain near threshold levels biological significance (Pilcher et al., 2023). Small copepods form prey base larval early juvenile pollock spring. Late juvenile pollock feed variety planktonic crustaceans, including large calanoid copepods euphausiids. Rapid Zooplankton Assessment southeastern Bering Sea spring noted moderate abundance small copepods, low abundance low lipid content large copepods euphausiids. fall, moderate abundance small copepods continued, abundance large copepods euphausiids remained low, abundances increased south north. northern Bering Sea fall, small copepods ubiquitous increased abundance south north, hot spots large copepods euphausiids observed around St. Lawrence Island (Kimmel et al. 2023). significant relationship exists abundance large, lipid-rich copepods recruitment survival juvenile pollock age-3 (Eisner et al., 2020). Low availability large copepod prey 2020 2022 may result reduced overwinter survival recruitment age-3 (2023 2025) (Yasumiishi et al., 2023b). Age-0 fish condition (samples collected southern northern Bering Sea surface trawl surveys), measured length-weight residuals, % lipid content, energy density residuals, respective time series averages 2023. Length-weight energy density residuals show decreasing trends since 2021 mean % lipid average (time series 2002-2023) since beginning recent warm stanza 2014 (Page et al., 2023). Juvenile (100-250 mm) fish condition southern Bering Sea decreased since 2021 adult fish condition decreased since 2019 2023 second lowest time series (1997-2023). Juvenile fish condition northern Bering Sea decreased since 2021 adult fish condition increased since 2021 2023 highest time series (2010, 2017, 2019, 2021-2023) (Prohaska Rohan, 2023).

title: Executive summary
text: Jellyfish feed primarily zooplankton small fish, therefore may compete prey resources juvenile adult life stages pollock. Jellyfish abundance southeastern Bering Sea shelf average time series (1982-2023; Buser, 2023), whereas abundance increased northern Bering Sea shelf (Buser, 2023; Yasumiishi et al., 2022c). Togiak herring biomass increasing recent years result strong 2016 2017 year classes also contributed high Prohibited Species Catch EBS pollock fishery (Joy et al., 2023). Yukon Kuskokwim River salmon runs experienced precipitous declines recent years (Whitworth et al., 2023), leading potential reduced competition prey resources stocks overlap, though slight increases observed juvenile Chinook chum salmon indices 2023 (Murphy et al., 2023). 2023, returns Bristol Bay sockeye salmon remained exceptionally high relative long-term average, lower recent record high numbers observed 2021 2022 (Cunningham Vega, 2023). Juvenile sockeye salmon feed zooplankton (competitors age-0 pollock) age-0 pollock (competitors adult pollock) warm years; adults feed zooplankton krill. Juvenile salmon condition 2022, measured energy density anomalies, negative species (except neutral Chinook salmon) southeastern Bering Sea positive species (except neutral sockeye salmon) northern Bering Sea (Fergusson et al., 2023). biomass pelagic foragers measured standard EBS bottom trawl survey decreased 34% 2022 2023 long-term mean (1982-2023) now third lowest value. guild largely driven walleye pollock decreased 25% 2022. Pacific herring decreased 75% time series high 2022, remain long-term mean (Siddon, 2023). impacts recent large year classes sablefish EBS ecosystem (prey, predators, competitors) remain largely unknown time, may compete pollock prey resources juveniles.

title: Executive summary
text: Pollock cannibalistic rates cannibalism might expected increase biomass older, larger fish increases (.e., aging large 2018 year class). 2023, average cold pool extent shelf, predation pressure cannibalism may mitigated thermal barrier adult pollock tend avoid cold bottom waters. However, biomass pelagic foragers, including adult pollock, dropped third lowest value time series 2023 (Siddon, 2023). Fur seal consumption adult pollock generally increases years juvenile pollock less abundant (Kuhn et al., 2019). However, Northern fur seal pup production St. Paul Island 2022 continued declining trend since 1998 may partially attributed low pup growth rates. potential predators juvenile pollock include jellyfish chum salmon. Jellyfish abundance southeastern Bering Sea shelf average time series (1982-2023; Buser, 2023), whereas abundance increased northern Bering Sea shelf (Buser, 2023; Yasumiishi et al., 2022c). Chum salmon abundance declining Yukon Kuskokwim Rivers since 2017 (Whitworth et al., 2023), trend also reflected commercial harvest data (Whitehouse, 2023).

what: Spatio-temporal treatment of survey data on pollock density
title: Executive summary
text: EBS pollock used data biomass per unit area grid cells corner stations 83-112 bottom trawl survey EBS, 1982-2023, including exploratory northern extension samples 2001, 2005, 2006, well 83-112 samples available NBS 1982, 1985, 1988, 1991, 2010, 2017-2023 (except 2020). NBS samples collected prior 2010 2018 follow 20 nautical mile sampling grid used 2010, 2017, 2019, 2021, 20232019, 2021–2023 surveys. Assimilating data therefore required extrapolating unsampled areas. , included spatially varying covariate cold-pool extent (Thorson 2019, (O’Leary et al. 2020). environmental data used covariates computed within R package coldpool (Rohan et al., 2022). used Poisson-link delta-model (Thorson 2018) involving two linear predictors gamma distribution model positive catch rates. extrapolated population density entire EBS NBS year, using extrapolation grids available within [FishStatsUtils] (https://github.com/James-Thorson-NOAA/FishStatsUtils). extrapolation grids defined using 3705 m (2 nmi) × 3705 m (2 nmi) cells; results 36,690 extrapolation-grid cells eastern Bering Sea 15,079 northern Bering Sea. used bilinear interpolation interpolate densities 750 “knots” extrapolation grid cells; knots approximately evenly distributed space, proportion dimensions extrapolation grid. estimated geometric anisotropy (spatial autocorrelation declines differing rates distance cardinal directions others), included spatial spatio-temporal term linear predictors. facilitate interpolation density unsampled years, specified spatio-temporal fields structured time AR(1) process (magnitude autocorrelation estimated fixed effect linear predictor). However, include temporal correlation intercepts, treated fixed effects linear predictor year. Finally, used epsilon bias-correction correct retransformation bias (Thorson Kristensen 2016). checked model fits evidence non-convergence confirming (1) derivative marginal likelihood respect fixed effect sufficiently small (less ~0.001) (2) Hessian matrix positive definite. checked evidence model fit computing Dunn-Smyth randomized quantile residuals (Dunn Smyth 1996) visualizing using quantile-quantile plot within DHARMa R package. also evaluated distribution residuals space year, inspected evidence residual spatio-temporal patterns.

title: Plot Stock-Recruitment Relationship (SRR) — plot_srr
text: function plots stock-recruitment relationship (SRR) using ggplot2. can handle multiple models provides flexibility display options.

title: Plot Stock-Recruitment Relationship (SRR) — plot_srr
code: plot_srr(   M,   ylab = "Recruits (age 1, millions)",   xlab = "Female spawning biomass (kt)",   ylim = NULL,   xlim = NULL,   alpha = 0.05,   ebar = "FALSE",   leglabs = NULL,   coverlap = FALSE,   sizein = 3,   sizeout = 2,   yrsin = 1977:2019 )

title: Plot Stock-Recruitment Relationship (SRR) — plot_srr
text: M list data structure containing model results. ylab Label y-axis. Default "Recruits (age 1, millions)". xlab Label x-axis. Default "Female spawning biomass (kt)". ylim Limits y-axis. Default NULL. xlim Limits x-axis. Default NULL. alpha Alpha ribbons indicating uncertainty. Default 0.05. ebar Logical, TRUE error bars plotted. Default FALSE. leglabs Custom labels legend. Default NULL. coverlap Logical, TRUE overlapping text labels checked prevented. Default FALSE. sizein Font size -sample text labels. Default 3. sizeout Font size --sample text labels. Default 2. yrsin Years considered -sample. Default 1977:2019.

title: Plot Stock-Recruitment Relationship (SRR) — plot_srr
text: ggplot object containing SRR plot.
